data.text: Contents
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (herein after referred to as the ‘Trust') has statutory obligations under the Health and Safety at Work Act (HSWA) to ensure the security and wellbeing of its employees and anyone affected by their work, so far as is reasonably practicable.

Trust activities pose a wide range of risks. Through the implementation of this policy, Directors, Managers and staff will be able to ensure that risks to security and wellbeing are controlled and reduced as far as is reasonably practicable within the Trust. Employees of the Trust will work collectively to discharge its security and wellbeing responsibilities to embed an intrinsically valued positive security and wellbeing culture throughout the sites, buildings and places of work of the Trust.

This is a Trust wide overarching Policy supported by a series of security related Policies and Procedures that more fully define and describe the variances and details across the range of properties and places of work used by the Trust to deliver its services to the community.
Scope

The purpose of this policy is to support the aims of the Trust in the delivery of high quality clinical services within a positive and secure environment. The Trust's security and welfare is a shared responsibility for its staff led and supported by the individuals named herein below who have been consigned a specific role to discharge.
This policy:

a) Sets out the accountability and authority arrangements for security throughout the Trust. The Trust's aim is to provide high quality healthcare within a safe and secure environment that protects all site users including patients, staff, visitors and their property and the physical assets of the Trust.

b) Identifies the security measures, practices and procedures in place to achieve the Trust's security goals within a user friendly environment in accordance with CQC guidance. Security, within and for the Trust, is the joint and singular responsibility of every member of the Trust's staff.

c) Enables the Trust to provide directions to staff that are entrusted to deal with the Trust's security provision. It supports the provision of high quality services to the community within a secure environment.

It is the Trusts intention to comply with relative legislation including but not limited to the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 and the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999, and to regularly review its policies and procedures for the security and wellbeing of staff, visitors and patients, Trust premises, equipment and information, to ensure continuing compliance.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
Duties within the Trust (Committees)
Trust Health and Safety Management Group

The Trust Health and Safety Management Group will ensure that reports received from the site Health and safety Forums, the SMD or the LSMS are reviewed and acted upon including passing information and guidance to the Trust SMD and the Trust LSMS.
Site Health and Safety Forums

The Trust's site Health and Safety Forums will ensure that reports received from the SMD, or LSMS or site staff are reviewed and acted upon including passing information and guidance to the Trust Health and Safety Management Group, the SMD and the LSMS as appropriate.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive) Chief Executive Officer / Directors

The Trust's Chief Executive Officer and its Directors are accountable for Health and Safety within the Trust and will ensure the understanding and application of Trust Policies as defined within the Trusts Health and Safety Policy.
Director of Security

The Trust‘s “Director of Security” (the “SMD”), a role held by the Chief Estates and Facilities Officer, will ensure that the Chief Executive and the Trust Board receive reports on security performance throughout the Trust. The SMD has statutory responsibility for overseeing the work of the security management and ensuring compliance with the standards and guidance set out for NHS providers by the NHS.

The SMD will ensure that a suitable person is appointed as the Trust Security Management Specialist (LSMS), and that the LSMS is given the necessary resources and support to carry out their role effectively and efficiently.
Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS)

The LSMS is the Trust's subject matter expert in relation to security. It is the responsibility of the LSMS to monitor compliance with this policy, with serious breaches and discrepancies being reported to the SMD. Breaches of the Policy will also be outlined in the LSMS's reports to the site Health and Safety Forums.

The LSMS has responsibilities for completion and submission of the Self Review Tool (SRT) annually via the NHS Portal and submission of Serious Incidents involving physical assault via NHS Serious Incident Reporting system (SIRS).

The LSMS will prepare an annual work programme to help meet defined national NHS security standards. The LSMS will provide support to the Trust in undertaking investigation and reporting of security related incidents. This may involve the LSMS carrying out surveys, audits and risk assessments.
The LSMS will also undertake as part of their duties:

Submit bi monthly updates to the respective Health & Safety Forums on Security Action Plan progress over the preceding quarter, including identifying developing trends/issues and progress with actions from the plan.
Submit an annual report that complies with the NHS format to the Board through the Trust H&S Group.
Provide advice and guidance on matters concerning security policy, strategy, risk, and governance.
Ensure security process' are align to the NHS standards of:
a) Strategic Governance
b) Inform and Involve
c) Prevent and Deter
d) Hold to Account
Facilitate the completion of the Security Review Tool (SRT)
Determine the annual Security Action Plan priorities
Raise strategic and operational risks which are identified or foreseeable
Provide support and assistance with security management issues e.g. security risk assessments, advice following a security incident
Will ensure that security measures are implemented to meet relevant guidance of the NHS.
Report security incidents.
Collate, analyse and identify security incident trends.
Providing advice and practical support to identify and implement suitable crime reduction measures.
Investigate breaches of security, as necessary, within the Trust.
Ensure that security management, including incident reporting and risk assessments, are integrated into systems for risk management throughout the Trust.
Carry out security inspections and risk assessments in premises used by the Trust.
Advise on strategic effectiveness of Conflict Resolution Training to meet NHS guidance.
Liaise with relevant agencies and/or authorities.
Monitor physical assault incidents.
Encourage the development of a security and welfare culture
Support managers and their staff with casework for potential criminal proceedings
Review and evaluate security related information from incident reports, risk assessments and other information sources.
Act as lead for Trust Lockdown Policy and systems.
Evaluate and liaise on security alerts issued by the NHS.
Report violence and aggression statistics annually to the NHS.
Attend regional NHS security meetings.
Security Managers

Site Security Managers will manage and monitor the security aspects of the Trusts sites in accordance with Trust Policies and Procedures and report to the LSMS on matters relating to Security as defined within this Policy and other Trust Policies and Procedures.
Security Officers

Site Security Officers will monitor the sites in accordance with Trust Policies and Procedures and report to the site Security Manager and/or the LSMS as appropriate on matters relating to Security as defined within this Policy and other Trust Policies and Procedures.
Duties of Employees

Employees of the Trust of any and all grades are expected and required to understand and follow this Security Policy in line with the Trust Health and Safety Policy under which staff are equally responsible for their acts and/or omissions and are an essential part of ensuring the security and welfare of their fellow staff, other site users and the Trust as a whole.
Security areas
Strategy

As part of the Trust's Security Management Strategy a formal approach will be taken by the SMD, LSMS and the Security Staff to address the following 6 security topic areas to ensure the issue of security is effectively managed across all aspects of its operations, including:
a) Manned Security – Security staff, communication, sites observation, risk management, site managing and monitoring.
b) Physical Security – building design, lighting, access and locking systems, tracking systems.
c) Emergency Response – Lockdowns, suspect packages and responding to security events and concerns.
d) Protection of staff – Lone working, duress/panic alarms, abuse and violence.
e) Information security – Alarms, CCTV
f) Staff security – ID cards.
g) Staff Security Awareness – Training
The Trust accepts its liabilities, risks and priorities include the provision of a safe and secure environment for:
i.  Staff and other site users and in particular vulnerable patients such as Infants (Maternity) and Children (Paediatric Services)
Together with an ability to respond quickly and effectively to internal and external incidents.
Vehicles

Security will provide support and guidance on the operation and safety of Trust vehicles. The Trust does not accept responsibility for non-Trust vehicles on Trust sites. Security will monitor vehicle safety on Trust sites.
Residences
The Trust does not accept liability for personal items within Trust provided residences. Trust Security will provide support and guidance on the operation and safety of Trust residences.
Technology

Technology is an essential and integral part of the security systems of the Trust. Information and Communication Technology is constantly evolving and the Trust needs to be kept up to date. The Trusts Security staff and systems will be supported by the Trust ICT Department to ensure adequate understanding, training, use of the Trusts ICT based Security systems.
ICT based systems used within Trust Security are to managed and operated by the Trusts Security staff who will ensure compliance with Trust Policies and Procedures in the use of such systems.
Training requirements

The Trust Health and Safety Management Group will provide guidance on the security training requirements for Trust staff based on the advice and guidance provided by the SMD and LSMS. Details of the approved security training requirements for Trust staff will be managed and maintained by HR.
Supporting information

The Trust provides supporting information and guidance on subjects relevant to its role in providing medical services to the community within a safe and secure environment. The position of the Trust and its security systems that enable and ensure such an environment are outlined within this policy.

Further detailed information is provided within supporting Policies, Procedures and other associated documents that cover the common and differing requirements of each of the Trusts sites and other places of work. The list of such documents will be maintained by the LSMS who will ensure that such documents are kept current and approved in accordance with Trust Document Control.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Trust Health and Safety Management Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Security guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Trust's Trust Health and Safety Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
